title: Timing attack towards endpoints on the web without CSRF

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
When logged in user on HackerOne visits another web page, remote web page could get conclusion regarding this data:

  • logged in user
  • number of triaged reports in the ~last month
  • number of new reports at the moment
  • number of closed reports ...

This conclusions are only from one endpoint https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=999999&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged .
Every endpoint that lists data without CSRF token, but holds interesting conclusion like ( does one program have triaged reports atm )

Description:
Yesterday I got this idea regarding getting conclusions from web endpoints that aren't protected by CSRF tokens. During the research I have employed the https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Resource_Timing_API . From the API we can read the load time for certain resource and having few another conditions enabled on some web api / endpoints we can get valuable conclusions. Check the following snippet:

<html>
<head>
<script>
function calculate_load_times() {
  // Check performance support
  if (performance === undefined) {
    console.log("= Calculate Load Times: performance NOT supported");
    return;
  }

  // Get a list of "resource" performance entries
  var resources = performance.getEntriesByType("resource");
  if (resources === undefined || resources.length <= 0) {
    console.log("= Calculate Load Times: there are NO `resource` performance records");
    return;
  }

  console.log("= Calculate Load Times");
  for (var i=0; i < resources.length; i++) {
    // Response time
    t = resources[i].responseEnd - resources[i].responseStart;
    console.log(t);
 }
}
</script>
</head>
<body>
<img id="grr" src="https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3%08&subject=%01&sort_type=upvotes&substates%5B%5D=spam">
</body>
</html>
  1. Host it on "attacker" domain
  2. If you are logged in on HackerOne and you visit attacker domain the script will work e.g. 200 response code will cause the script to measure the load time, if not load time won't be shown ( http 400, 500 status codes)
  3. Find interesting endpoints that could deliver conclusions or static data that could help in future.

Detailed description:

At the moment will deliver always constant output for any logged in user ~750b: https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=999999&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged

This one too ~9200b : https://hackerone.com/programs/search.json?query=IBB&sort=published_at%3Adescending&page=1

This means we as logged in users could measure the average size in bytes from those two responses and this values are almost the same for any logged in user on HackerOne.

Now when victim ( logged in on HackerOne ) visits the "attacker" web site, the attacker web site could measure the time needed for many calls towards this endpoints => we can get idea regarding the internet speed of victim e.g.

Measure average page load for search.json with this script 1.php ( host it, visit it logged on H1 and type calculate_load_times() in browser console )

<html>
<head>
<script>
function calculate_load_times() {
  // Check performance support
  if (performance === undefined) {
    console.log("= Calculate Load Times: performance NOT supported");
    return;
  }

  // Get a list of "resource" performance entries
  var resources = performance.getEntriesByType("resource");
  if (resources === undefined || resources.length <= 0) {
    console.log("= Calculate Load Times: there are NO `resource` performance records");
    return;
  }

  console.log("= Calculate Load Times");
  for (var i=0; i < resources.length; i++) {
    // Response time
    t = resources[i].responseEnd - resources[i].responseStart;
    console.log(t);
  }
}
</script>
</head>
<!-- https://hackerone.com/programs/search?query=test&sort=published_at%3Adescending&page=1 -->
<body>
<?php
for ($i=0;$i<30;$i++){
echo '<img id=grr"'.$i.'" src="https://hackerone.com/programs/search.json?query=IBB&sort=published_at%3Adescending&page=1&rnd='.rand(1,5000).'">
';
}
?>
</body>
</html>

Same for bugs.json with following 2.php (host it, visit it logged on H1 and type calculate_load_times() in browser console )

<html>
<head>
<script>
function calculate_load_times() {
  // Check performance support
  if (performance === undefined) {
    console.log("= Calculate Load Times: performance NOT supported");
    return;
  }

  // Get a list of "resource" performance entries
  var resources = performance.getEntriesByType("resource");
  if (resources === undefined || resources.length <= 0) {
    console.log("= Calculate Load Times: there are NO `resource` performance records");
    return;
  }

  console.log("= Calculate Load Times");
  for (var i=0; i < resources.length; i++) {


    // Response time
    t = resources[i].responseEnd - resources[i].responseStart;
    console.log(t);


  }
}
</script>
</head>
<!-- https://hackerone.com/programs/search?query=test&sort=published_at%3Adescending&page=1 -->
<body>
<?php
for ($i=0;$i<30;$i++){
echo '<img id=grr"'.$i.'" src="https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=999999&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged&rnd='.rand(1,5000).'">';
}
?>
</body>
</html>

Now having this values about the load time we can simple calculate the average time for loading for each of the img elements => we can calculate approximately the internet speed of the victim towards HackerOne endpoints at that moment. Having the approximate internet speed and chance for measuring time needed for load of some interesting resource we can learn from this side channel attack if victim have created report in the last few days: https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3480&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=new
or
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3479&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=new
...
Using the same scripts from above with specified urls. In this last urls exploiting fact is the guessing the time of the report based on report id.
From measured time, we can get conclusion even for the number of reports / records in the response if we divide the content size with average size of one (json) record. :)

As extra, this kind of attacks could be performed against H1 programs in order to get knowledge if some program have triaged reports, new, closed, ...

I have performed PoC calculations based on 30 requests per endpoint from my localhost and works like a charm :)

Optional: Your Environment (Browser version, Device, etc)

  • any modern browser

Optional: Supporting Material/References (Screenshots)

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Resource_Timing_API/Using_the_Resource_Timing_API

Impact

Any endpoint on the net is vulnerable on this type of attack due the fact it is side channel attack which could be prevented only if CSRF tokens are supplied in the request as variables. This way, using this attack approach could be ex filtrated /learned many many information from visiting users who are logged in on services that host sensitive data regarding them. I'll continue with this research

From measured time, we can get conclusion even for the number of reports / records in the response if we divide the content size with average size of one (json) record. :)

Should be:

From measured time, we can get conclusion even for the number of reports / records in the response if we divide the `calculated` content size with average size of one (json) record - we can find an average due the fact many of the properties are with fixed length and few are variable which size doesn't affect the proximity. :)

activities.message: Hi @slavco - thanks for your report, this looks pretty promising! For the sake of a proof of concept, would you mind providing a PoC that tries to guess the number of reports for the `security` program in the `new`, `triaged`, and `resolved` state? Thanks in advance, it's much appreciated!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @slavco - thanks for your report, this looks pretty promising! For the sake of a proof of concept, would you mind providing a PoC that tries to guess the number of reports for the security program in the new, triaged, and resolved state? Thanks in advance, it's much appreciated!

activities.message:
Hi, I have created a very simple demo that calculations are based on average values ( not employed good numerical methods for better estimation, but will be in future ofc. ).

Demo url data dumps generated ( measured time - directory listing is enabled ):
https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/data/ 

How to use:

I have performed tests against: 

https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=33&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged

`text_query` must have at least one character, due complexity on server side - returns lower values.
When you decide regarding your endpoint, then visit the following urls one by one:

1. https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/1.php
2. https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/2.php
3. https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/3.php?query=33 - this call must have parameter `query` which will be the same as `text_query` you use.
4. Visit them one by one
5. Visit https://hqpeak.com/hackeronePoCftw/miner.php 
6. If you have stable internet connection then change the `query` parameter and verify results on your side opening 
`https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=GET_QUERY_VARIABLE&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged`
e.g. `1.php` and `2.php` will almost always return same results.

More stable internet connection, better results, but if you don't have stable internet connection then for every demo reload 1.php, 2.php and 3.php?query=your_val.
 
Demo is based on simple average values and doesn't find filed or prolonged requests, but it is quite easy to be implemented...

activities.message: Regarding the final e.g. very good exploit for this vulnerability would require creating smarter JS client ( dynamic and timed creation of `` elements, optimization of internet connection speed measurement, filtering of failed or prolonged requests based on the retrieved data, better estimation of size of the record due it is send gzip-ed and few another aspects ), but overall it works. From use cases I have think about, beside minimg, could also be used as CSRF exploitation of blind SQLi.
activities.markdown_message: Regarding the final e.g. very good exploit for this vulnerability would require creating smarter JS client ( dynamic and timed creation of <img> elements, optimization of internet connection speed measurement, filtering of failed or prolonged requests based on the retrieved data, better estimation of size of the record due it is send gzip-ed and few another aspects ), but overall it works. From use cases I have think about, beside minimg, could also be used as CSRF exploitation of blind SQLi.

activities.message: Hi @slavco - it might actually work, but because the `subject` is empty, so it'll always default to an empty set. The first time I ran it, it gave me -22 records, the seconds time -1. Would you mind updating the `subject` to `security` on your server so I can test this with actual reports? Thanks! I'm wondering how practical this is to actually determine the contents of a report through searching, but being able to get the counts would already be pretty cool. Thanks!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @slavco - it might actually work, but because the subject is empty, so it'll always default to an empty set. The first time I ran it, it gave me -22 records, the seconds time -1. Would you mind updating the subject to security on your server so I can test this with actual reports? Thanks! I'm wondering how practical this is to actually determine the contents of a report through searching, but being able to get the counts would already be pretty cool. Thanks!

Changed :) 
The trick is you need to hit f5 few times, first 1, 2 and last 3.php . As I mentioned atm it takes average value without cleaning the edge values - data clustering on this values using cosine similarity will do the job more than good :)

activities.message: I can send you the code, so you can play locally. Just second to upload the scripts here.

activities.message: place them where you want and next to them create web writable `data` directory :)
activities.markdown_message: place them where you want and next to them create web writable data directory :)

activities.message: In the `miner.php` 185B hardcoded value is average value of one record from json array. It is considered fact that responses are gzip-ed and that is why there is 2100B (some request with 1+ records) -800B (estimated empty response) / 7 (number of records in my case) in order to get some approximation. I need it to multiply with the speed per calculated average time. With better measurements and clustering results will be quite effective.
activities.markdown_message: In the miner.php 185B hardcoded value is average value of one record from json array. It is considered fact that responses are gzip-ed and that is why there is 2100B (some request with 1+ records) -800B (estimated empty response) / 7 (number of records in my case) in order to get some approximation. I need it to multiply with the speed per calculated average time. With better measurements and clustering results will be quite effective.

activities.message: If you run the scripts locally intervene in the .txt files to remove the edge values and you will have the results with the user endpoint. Also change the 185B variable for `security` parameter appropriately. Another interesting thing I have noticed is server side complexity on H1 is far lower when `text_query` doesn't have any value, so when you test, make sure it has one :)
activities.markdown_message: If you run the scripts locally intervene in the .txt files to remove the edge values and you will have the results with the user endpoint. Also change the 185B variable for security parameter appropriately. Another interesting thing I have noticed is server side complexity on H1 is far lower when text_query doesn't have any value, so when you test, make sure it has one :)

activities.message: Hi @slavco - hmm, I like your approach a lot, but I can't get it to be as precise as I want to for it to be a security vulnerability. I've reduced the number of `img` tags per page load to 10 to avoid the browser to wait for other request to finish, which artificially increases the RTT. This is not something you want for it to be used when calculating the averages. However, when doing so, I'm still getting relatively high numbers compared to what I should get. I'm seeing results of 50 reports whereas the actual search only returns 7 items. Any other ideas on how to make it more precise? Otherwise I'm leaning towards closing this out as informative for the time being. I'm happy to throw in some swag for your efforts and approach, I love the creativity!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @slavco - hmm, I like your approach a lot, but I can't get it to be as precise as I want to for it to be a security vulnerability. I've reduced the number of img tags per page load to 10 to avoid the browser to wait for other request to finish, which artificially increases the RTT. This is not something you want for it to be used when calculating the averages. However, when doing so, I'm still getting relatively high numbers compared to what I should get. I'm seeing results of 50 reports whereas the actual search only returns 7 items. Any other ideas on how to make it more precise? Otherwise I'm leaning towards closing this out as informative for the time being. I'm happy to throw in some swag for your efforts and approach, I love the creativity!

activities.message:
Same old bad rendering of screen recorder, but miner not rounded values could be seen and endpoints from my account are the following:
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=33&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged - 3 reports
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged - 7 reports
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=4&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged -5 reports
https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=40&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged - 1 report

All of them were guessed with this employed basic approximations. Issue exists atm and is caused by the fact that url could be guessed e.g. there isn't token in it. 
I think should be considered as a issue, due the fact interesting information is leaked.

activities.message: Hi @slavco - thanks for following up. I have unfortunate news, and you can blame me for it personally. While going throw your report I realized that I had seen it before, but it was a while back (4 years to be exact). The endpoints changed (`/reports` became `/bugs`) overtime, but the attack is still the same. I'm going ahead and add you to the original report. We'll have an internal discussion if it's time to revisit our earlier decision to punt on the fix. I'm sorry to have asked you all these questions, it wasn't my intention to end up closing it as a duplicate. Because of that, I'll throw in some swag here. We're looking forward to receive more reports from you in the future. Again, apologies from my end. Good luck and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @slavco - thanks for following up. I have unfortunate news, and you can blame me for it personally. While going throw your report I realized that I had seen it before, but it was a while back (4 years to be exact). The endpoints changed (/reports became /bugs) overtime, but the attack is still the same. I'm going ahead and add you to the original report. We'll have an internal discussion if it's time to revisit our earlier decision to punt on the fix. I'm sorry to have asked you all these questions, it wasn't my intention to end up closing it as a duplicate. Because of that, I'll throw in some swag here. We're looking forward to receive more reports from you in the future. Again, apologies from my end. Good luck and happy hacking!

activities.message: We'll send you some cool goodies!
activities.markdown_message: We'll send you some cool goodies!

activities.message: Thx for the swag, but must agree that my report goes much beyond another ones - delivers information, even delivers real results. I still don't agree with the duplicate. I'll continue my research for sure ( I have mentioned clustering and numerical analysis  ), but I was hoping that I would continue it relaxed. Nvm, let it flow :)

activities.message: Yeah, I'm not disagreeing with that, but the problem is the same. Different ways of exploiting it doesn't mean the root cause isn't the same (e.g. we allow `GET` requests to query this type of information). @cache-money, who also filed a duplicate, was also able to show results. I'd encourage you to continue the research, but if it comes down to rewarding a bounty, we'd reward the original finder. We might throw in a bonus, but that wouldn't be the same as the original bounty. I'm happy to be convinced that we need to fix this. Until then, we'll keep it closed as Informative. Good luck and I'm looking forward to your findings!
activities.markdown_message: Yeah, I'm not disagreeing with that, but the problem is the same. Different ways of exploiting it doesn't mean the root cause isn't the same (e.g. we allow GET requests to query this type of information). @cache-money, who also filed a duplicate, was also able to show results. I'd encourage you to continue the research, but if it comes down to rewarding a bounty, we'd reward the original finder. We might throw in a bonus, but that wouldn't be the same as the original bounty. I'm happy to be convinced that we need to fix this. Until then, we'll keep it closed as Informative. Good luck and I'm looking forward to your findings!

activities.message:
Ha, interesting feature of the attack surface!
Attack surface is based on time => all we need is timing of the victim and nothing more - calculations are done on the server side or offline. If I send some link toward someone and I want to know how many reports are new, triaged, closed in certain period of time  ( id of the report is incremental numeric value ).

So, in order to get the right answer regarding this information ( victim number of reports per type / period of time ) we need to measure the following:

a. Timing towards "empty" response e.g. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=99999999999999999999&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged
b. Timing towards endpoint from which we need to extract data e.g. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged

How we will extract data: 
1. we measure the responses from our end
2. From (a) timing results we get knowledge regarding the internet speed of the victim towards H1 servers at the time
3. From (b) timing we derive the results in the form of response size and due the fact we can estimate each record size => we have number of records.

I think not it is more clear why this report is very very different than another ones. 
 - It strictly says that need to be added CSRF tokens in the request.   
 - It exploits the report id as time traveling value 

Regarding the statement that root cause is already reported I would like to state that my approach most probably has already pushed updates towards the system and those reports are very very old. That is why I'm continuing my research and I continue with strong arguments why report should be separate. Btw I haven't meet this type of attack anywhere else, just got inspired by that http 500 null string error :)
activities.markdown_message:
Ha, interesting feature of the attack surface!
Attack surface is based on time => all we need is timing of the victim and nothing more - calculations are done on the server side or offline. If I send some link toward someone and I want to know how many reports are new, triaged, closed in certain period of time ( id of the report is incremental numeric value ).

So, in order to get the right answer regarding this information ( victim number of reports per type / period of time ) we need to measure the following:

a. Timing towards "empty" response e.g. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=99999999999999999999&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged
b. Timing towards endpoint from which we need to extract data e.g. https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?text_query=3&subject=&sort_type=pg_search_rank&substates%5B%5D=triaged

How we will extract data:

  1. we measure the responses from our end
  2. From (a) timing results we get knowledge regarding the internet speed of the victim towards H1 servers at the time
  3. From (b) timing we derive the results in the form of response size and due the fact we can estimate each record size => we have number of records.

I think not it is more clear why this report is very very different than another ones.

  • It strictly says that need to be added CSRF tokens in the request.
  • It exploits the report id as time traveling value

Regarding the statement that root cause is already reported I would like to state that my approach most probably has already pushed updates towards the system and those reports are very very old. That is why I'm continuing my research and I continue with strong arguments why report should be separate. Btw I haven't meet this type of attack anywhere else, just got inspired by that http 500 null string error :)

activities.message:
> I'm continuing my research and I continue with strong arguments why report should be separate

I'm not convinced yet that this is a separate issue, but feel free to continue to look at it and proof me wrong. It's a known vulnerability that the RTT of some endpoints can be used to determine the number of objects. However, we've fine with this, which is why we closed the original report as Informative. Even if this wouldn't be a duplicate, we'd still close it as Informative. Only if you'd find something crazy we'd be prioritizing this and we'd be happy to give you credit for finding something we didn't know about yet. Looking forward to hearing more from you in the future!
activities.markdown_message:
I'm continuing my research and I continue with strong arguments why report should be separate

I'm not convinced yet that this is a separate issue, but feel free to continue to look at it and proof me wrong. It's a known vulnerability that the RTT of some endpoints can be used to determine the number of objects. However, we've fine with this, which is why we closed the original report as Informative. Even if this wouldn't be a duplicate, we'd still close it as Informative. Only if you'd find something crazy we'd be prioritizing this and we'd be happy to give you credit for finding something we didn't know about yet. Looking forward to hearing more from you in the future!

activities.message: I have filled in separate report 350432 and named it Information disclosure, it carefully describes the attack surface (here I had many points and most probably complete conversation is more than confusing ). If you still think it is fine with anyone that any logged in person on HackerOne risks disclosure of number critical reports triaged last week towards 3rd party web site as a fine with you, then ok, let it be informative and we can make the report public 350432. I think it has very bigger impact than grade you give it, so I would like to make a nice technical write up. Is it ok?

summaries.content:
[mslavco](https://twitter.com/mslavco) submitted a report to us that identified a way to extract certain information about reports. In our testing the method was not reliable enough to exploit this in the wild, which is why no fix was prioritized. In 2019 this endpoint will likely be deprecated and we'll move to GraphQL to query the information. This new endpoint will require a token, which means it won't be susceptible to the described attack. We'd like to thank [mslavco](https://twitter.com/mslavco) for their report.

Even though we don't publicly disclose reports that weren't closed as Resolved, we're making an exception here for transparency's sake. Multiple accusations, by different actors, have been made of harassment, hate speech and discrimination by the reporter. We've investigated the accusations and determined that this was not the case.

Also see #350432.
